description.narrative: SUPPORT TO POVERTY REDUCTION

title.narrative: Evaluation of the Poverty Reduction Programme in Namibia
UNDP_Reduction of Human Poverty Evaluation in Namibia Report_final version 24 June 2013

description.narrative: This project is aimed at supporting the Government especially the National Planning Commission Secretariat in the context of Vision 2030 and the MDG's
independent political entity

1.# of officials from Government Ministries, Agencies, and Regional Councils trained on Result-based management, medium term expenditure framework, monitoring and evaluation. 2. Integrated Result-based management and monitoring and evaluation system for NDP3 in place.

comment.narrative: 1. No Integrated Result-based Management and Monitoring and Evaluation system for NDP 3 in place.

Improve the capacity of National Planning Commission on data analysis and reporting through the NIMD and Poverty Mapping Support NPC with the generation of the baseline data on the root causes of poverty in the country, which resulted in the development of the Namibian Index of Multiple Deprivations (NIMD) and Namibia Poverty Mapping reports. Support NPC to development the capacity of National Development Advisors in the area of poverty and social impact analysis. This support directly contributed to the achievement of NDP4. Training of National Development Advisors to establish policy researchers. Support the newly formed Ministry of Poverty Eradication and Social Welfare to develop the National White Paper on Wealth Redistribution and Poverty Eradication Support GRN to develop the Final 2015 National Millennium Development Goals progress report.

The generation of the baseline data on the root causes of poverty in the country improved through the development of the Namibian Index of Multiple Deprivations (NIMD) and Namibia Poverty Mapping reports. Capacity of NPC National Development Advisors in the area of poverty and social impact analysis developed and strengthened through training provided by the Stellenbosch University . UNDP supported the newly formed Ministry of Poverty Eradication and Social Welfare to develop the National White Paper on Wealth Redistribution and Poverty Eradication. The regional dialogues in all 14 regions on status of poverty undertaken. The National Conference on Wealth Redistribution and Poverty Eradication undertaken. Report is available. Final 2015 National Millennium Development Goals progress report developed and finalized.
Project operational closure in 2016. The new replacement project started in 2016: Support to Poverty Reduction
Project operational closure in 2016. The new replacement project started in 2016: Support to Poverty Reduction
N/A
N/A

description.narrative: Support to Gender Equality
Support to Gender Equality
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - social services (incl youth development and women+ children)

National Gender Policy and its National Plan of Action developed National GBV Plan of Action developed Capacity of MGECW Staff enhanced National Coordination Mechanism established and approved by Cabinet Gender Responsive Budget directives in place and capacity of all O/M/A developed Male Engagement Action Plan developed

comment.narrative: 1. 16% of successful prosecution of rape and domestic violence cases 2. 1997 National Gender Policy and 1998 to 2003 Plan of Action 3. 2000 to 2005 number of rape cases were at 39% 4. Gender Based Violence database not reflecting all required gender variables 5. No Coordination Mechanism exist 6. Male Engagement initiatives in Namibia non-existent

Implementation all components of CM at all levels especially the GAC to provide for the much needed political support GRB Training Manuals and Guidelines to be finalized, printed and distributed Training of Trainers on Gender Responsive Budgeting to be undertaken All GBV Campaign materialize to be reviewed and developed for the implementation of comprehensive GBV Zero Tolerance Campaign Male Engagement activities to be intensified Standard operating procedures and protocols for GBV developed

In 2015, the MGECW supported by United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) commissioned analyses of the respective budgets and MTEF proposals in 2015 for seven Ministries namely Ministry of Education, Arts and Culture; Ministry of Defense; Ministry of Health and Social Services; Ministry of Safety and Security; Ministry of Works and Transport; Ministry Higher Education, Training and Innovation and Ministry of Finance, which collectively are allocated about 70% of the total expenditure budget to assess progress in the implementation of the Cabinet Directive on GRB. The findings of the analyses introduces strategies for addressing challenges in GRB and map out a strategy of on how to strengthen GRB in Namibia. The assessment was followed by a TOT Workshop for the assessed ministries to enable them further strengthen GRB practice in the respective institutions. The TOT workshop attracted 32 participants, consisting of 22 women and 10 men, of the participants, 3 are part of the pioneer group of the Master of Arts in Gender Studies Course at the University of Namibia which was establish through funds and technical assistance of UNDP who were specially invited to take part and provide their expert advice.
Through a MOU between civil societies in responding to the strategic interventions in the National GBV Plan of Action to engage men in key male dominated sectors in the prevention of gender based violence the Football Fraternity was selected as a focus group this year. 18 Football players from the 8 of top teams in the Namibian Premier League where trained and guidelines materials have been developed for them. The key result is to introduce, increase and strengthen the involvement of the soccer fraternities in efforts aimed at addressing Gender Based Violence . Banners were developed with messages of GBV and will be used as awareness raising tools during all Premier League Football matches.
In 2013/2014 the Multidisciplinary Research Centre and the United Nations D

title.narrative: Concentrating Solar Power Technology Transfer for Electr

description.narrative: Concentrating Solar Power Technology Transfer for Electricity Generation in Namibia (CSP TT) NAM.

title.narrative: Project Dcoument Signature Page Concentrating Solar Power Technology Transfer for Electricity Generation in Namibia (CSP TT) NAM
Concentrated Solar Power Technology Transfer for Electricity Generation in Namibia

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
Concentrating Solar Power Technology Transfer for Electricity Generation in Namibia (CSP TT) NAM.
independent political entity
Energy - power generation
50 MW CSP Solar Power Plant set up by 2017/18

comment.narrative: No single CSP Solar Power Plant in Namibia.

1) Local entrepreneurs are engaged in the manufacturing, supply and installation of CSP systems 2) Increased investments in CSP technology applications in Namibia 3) Increased installed capacity of CSP plants in Namibia

2) Ongoing; site selection of 5 target solar ground measurement sites were finalised. The contracts of contractor to install ground measurement stations at 3 were finalised. The draft Renewable Energy Policy incorporating CSP was formulated. The draft IPP Framework Guidelines was obtained1) Ongoing; The CSP capacity building workshop for 40 entrepreneurs, engineers, policy-makers and academia was conducted. Knowlege-sharing and technology transfer partnership with SolarPaces and Ministry of Mines and Energy was finalised. The CSP Interest Database for linking local and international stakeholders is in place with 50 and 30 entries; The project is currently drafting the partnership Agreement Templates. 10 local entrepreneurs were engaged in enhancing capacity and interest in expanding into manufacuring, financing and the provision of CSP linked services. 3) Ongoing; the draft Implementation Agreements Framework was formulated. The draft EIA for one of the 5 ground measurement sites available and being refined for CSP plant criteria.

Output 1: 1. Procurement package in place to source first PPP for CSP plant of 125MW.
Output 2: 1. At least one quarter (1,000) households of the SCORE target population reached; replicable and appropriate peri/urban agriculture model developed for Namibia
Output 3: 1. Three CFs adopted sustainable production technologies 2. Two hundred (200) smallholder farmers adopt climate resilient agricultural methods 3. At least two policies and strategies incorporate climate change
Output 4: 1. Five thematic reports and 1 summary report delivered and approved 2. Report on national conference on Extractives produced 3. One concept note delivered on youth engagement in the extractives sector.
Output 5: 1. terminal evaluation commissioned 2. Two field assurance missions conducted per project 3. 95% of total approved budget disbursed.

Output 1: 1. Procurement package in place to source first PPP for CSP plant of 125MW.
Output 2: 1. At least one quarter (1,000) households of the SCORE target population reached; replicable and appropriate peri/urban agriculture model developed for Namibia
Output 3: 1. Three CFs adopted sustainable production technologies 2. Two hundred (200) smallholder farmers adopt climate resilient agricultural methods 3. At least two policies and strategies incorporate climate change
Output 4: 1. Five thematic reports and 1 summary report delivered and approved 2. Report on national conference on Extractives was not produced, as the conference was postponed to future years 3. One concept note on youth engagement in the extractives sector to be developed in 2017.
Output 5: 1. Terminal evaluation for the CSP TT project was not commissioned in 2016 2. Two field assurance missions conducted per project 3. 95% of total approved budget disbursed.

description.narrative: To increase the share of renewable energies in the Namibian energy mix by developing the necessary technological framework and conditions for the successful transfer and deployment of CSP technology for ongrid power generation

Cumulative direct postproject CO2 emission reduction resulting from the investment in CSP by endofproject EoP Mtonnes CO2
share of CSP in the power generation mix of Namibia by EoP

Cumulative direct postproject CO2 emission reduction resulting from the investment in CSP by endofproject EoP Mtonnes CO2
share of CSP in the power generation mix of Namibia by EoP
NB Revision of Indicator targets As per the findings of the MidTerm Review these indicators were overambitious and cannot be achieved during the project timeframe Indeed it is logically impossible to expect a project to achieve postproject emission reductions by the end of the project The indicators were not sufficiently amended to reflect the project redesign requested by GEFSec during the protracted project preparation phase Specifically the indicators do not accurately reflect the revised goal of the project which is to have the feasibility study for a CSP plant in place by the end of the project not to construct the plant itself
Increased installed capacity of CSP plants in Namibia

description.narrative: Implementation of the Integrated Fire Management Strategy
8 Number of hectares under improved integrated fire management

comment.narrative: SOPs are currently not in place
100 of Namibias PAs 135906 ha

National Fire Management Strategy developed and approved
ToR for development of SOP for each PA finalized
Improved Fire Management practices Namely a Introduction of Early Burning to minimize biomas fire load as a strategy to counter adverse fire impacts during the fire season b maintenance of firebreaks and c creation of new fire breaks where necessary to contain limit and confine fire outbreaks to smaller areas burned patches at a time For the reporting period these activities were predominantly implemented in Etosha 2227000 ha Khaudum 384000 ha and Bwabwata 610000 ha 3221000 ha in total
